properties.label: Gibeon

hypotheses.notes: Pleiades ID 687900. Widely accepted identification with high scholarly consensus (>95%).
OpenBible confidence: 91.7%. Minor coordinate variation from Pleiades.

properties.notes: Modern site el-Jib (Al-Jib), West Bank. Located 9km NW of Jerusalem.

properties.label: Jerusalem

hypotheses.notes: Pleiades ID 687928. Precise location (±5-10m accuracy). City of David archaeological site represents core settlement.

properties.notes: Jerusalem Old City. One of the five Amorite kings who formed coalition against Gibeon. Ruled by King Adoni-Zedek.

properties.label: Hebron

hypotheses.notes: Tel Hebron (Tel Rumeida), Hebron, West Bank. Elevation 936m. Extensive Bronze Age fortifications documented.

properties.notes: Ruled by King Hoham. Massive Middle Bronze Age II (1750-1550 BCE) city wall documented. Multiple conquest traditions in biblical text.

properties.label: Jarmuth

hypotheses.notes: Tel Yarmut, Israel. 26km WSW of Jerusalem, Shephelah region. Elevation 405m. Now Israeli National Park.

properties.notes: Ruled by King Piram. Led coalition against Gibeon with other four Amorite kings.

properties.label: Lachish

hypotheses.notes: Tel Lachish (Tell el-Duweir), Israel. 40km SW of Jerusalem. Extensively excavated, 100% scholarly consensus.

properties.notes: Ruled by King Japhia. Major fortified city, Israeli National Park. Extensive archaeological documentation from Starkey (1932-38) and Tel Aviv University (1973-87) excavations.

properties.label: Eglon

hypotheses.notes: Tel 'Eton (Tel Aitun), Israel. Current scholarly consensus. Third largest site in Judah after Jerusalem and Lachish. 12km SE of Lachish, 17km SW of Hebron.
Tel el-Hesi. Albright's 1924 identification, now rejected by most scholars in favor of Tel 'Eton.

properties.notes: Ruled by King Debir. Scholarly identification shifted from Tel el-Hesi (outdated) to Tel 'Eton (current consensus).

properties.label: Debir

hypotheses.notes: Khirbet Rabud, West Bank. Current scholarly consensus based on Moshe Kochavi excavations (1968-69). Only Late Bronze Age city south of Jerusalem with upper/lower water sources.
Tell Beit Mirsim. Albright's identification, now abandoned by most scholars in favor of Khirbet Rabud.

properties.notes: 13km SW of Hebron. Scholarly identification shifted from Tell Beit Mirsim (Albright) to Khirbet Rabud (Kochavi 1968-69).

properties.label: Makkedah

hypotheses.notes: Khirbet el-Qom. Possible identification, 14km W of Hebron. Idumean ostraca mention 'Maqqedah'.
Khirbet el-Kheishum. Alternative proposed location. No scholarly consensus.

properties.notes: UNCERTAIN LOCATION. Cave tradition important (5 kings hid in cave, Josh 10:16-27). Multiple proposed locations, no current scholarly consensus.

properties.label: Libnah

hypotheses.notes: Tel Burna, Israel. High scholarly confidence (W. Albright, Y. Aharoni, excavation team consensus). 35km SW of Jerusalem, Shephelah region.

properties.notes: One of 13 Kohanic cities. Late Bronze Age cultic finds support Canaanite occupation. Border between Judah and Philistia. Excavated by Ariel University (2010-2024).

properties.label: Azekah

hypotheses.notes: Tel Azekah (Tell Zakariyeh), Israel. 26km NW of Hebron, Elah Valley. Elevation 347m. Strategic location, extensively excavated.

properties.notes: Scene of David vs Goliath. Destroyed by Sennacherib 701 BCE. LMLK seals found. Israeli National Park (Britannia Park). Excavations by Bliss & Macalister (1897-1900) and Lautenschläger Expedition (2012-present).
